title: Training School Programme
text:
The training school will take place over five days, beginning with structured teaching and hands on activities and allowing time towards the end of the week to discuss how to apply these good practices to the applicants own circumstances.
This page provides the programme of the training school, the topics covered and, in due course, links to the training materials.

title: Training School Programme
text:
üíª Topics
Below is a preliminary list of subjects covered for each section of the course. Further details will be provided closer to the time of the training school.

Day 1 - Introduction

Welcome
Introduction to the ADS
Attendee introductions
Discussion: Set personal trainee objectives.
The FAIR and CARE data principles



Day 2 - Data Management

Where to start - Knowing and Organising Your Data
ADS Guides to Good Practice and ADS Instructions for depositors
An Introduction to Data Management
Planning Selection and Retention Strategies
The Importance of Metadata - Discovery and Preservation
Introduction to Thesauri and Standardised Vocabularies



Day 3 - Digital Preservation and Quality Assurance

An Introduction to Digital Preservation
Migration and Normalisation of Files
Workflows for Archives - Tour of the ADS archiving workflow
Discussion - share your digital archiving workflows



Day 4 - Dissemination and Data Reuse

Discussion - share your digital archiving workflows
Quality Assurance
Data Standards
Monitoring data and data integrity
Where is our Data: Reaching for the clouds
Facilitating Data Reuse
Looking to the Future at ADS



üßë One one one sessions with ADS Experts
Participants will be matched with an appropriate expert from the ADS to discuss their specific needs and requirements for their organisation or research project. We recommend that each participant come to the training school with a specific requirement in mind, however, we can also help to provide support during the training sessions. These sessions will take place on the last two days of the training school.

title: ADS Transnational Access Training School
text:
This training school will introduce participants to current good practice for data stewardship and provide them the skills to apply these practices to their own circumstances. The training school will focus on the topics of digital preservation and data management with a focus on archaeological data, but will be applicable to most data types used in the Arts and Humanities. Training will be provided by experts from the ADS and will include time to discuss the needs of your own organisation or project one-on-one with experts from the ADS.
Topics covered in this training school will include:
For more detailed information about the curriculum for this training school please see the Programme pages.

title: ADS Transnational Access Training School
text:
Training School 2024
üìÜ Date 11 to 15 November 2024
üåç Location Kings Manor, Exhibition Square, York YO1 7EP, United Kingdom
This year the training school will take place in person in York, UK and will run over a week in November. Please see the General information pages for more details.

The training school is provided as part of transnational access scheme provided by the ATRIUM Project and is hosted by the Archaeology Data Service, a digital repository hosted by the Department of Archaeology at the University of York. This training school will be held annually from 2024 to 2026. Each year the ADS will host up to 8 applicants for 1 week.

title: The Archaeology Data Service
text: The Archaeology Data Service (ADS) is the leading accredited repository in the UK for archaeology and historic environment data. With over 25 years of experience the ADS supports research, learning and teaching with free, high quality and dependable digital resources.

title: The Archaeology Data Service
text:
üë©‚Äçüè´ Your instructors
Dr Nicky Garland 
Nicky is the Training and Communications Manager at the Archaeology Data Service (ADS). Nicky is an archaeologist with experience of teaching and training in both developer-led archaeology and academia.
Nicky is the course convenor for this Training School and the contact for all of your questions.
Dr Tim Evans 
Tim is the Deputy Director of the ADS. Tim holds responsibility for all day-to-day operational issues at the ADS, and alongside our Director Prof Julian Richards is responsible for strategic development.
Dr Katie Green 
Kate is the Collections Development Manager of the ADS. Katie‚Äôs main role is to develop and promote ADS digital preservation services across the UK archaeology community.
Dr Holly Wright 
Holly is the Research Projects Manager of the ADS. Holly manages and implements the ADS contribution to a range of major international research projects.
Kieron Niven 
Kieron is a Digital Archivist and Data Standards Lead at the ADS. Kieron has a wealth of experience in data standards in digital preservation and has contributed to the Guides to Good Practice - a series of guidelines that provide important information on the creation and archiving of data within a number of key project types.

ATRIUM
Advancing FronTier Research In the Arts and hUManities (ATRIUM) is a European Commission funded project that aims to exploit and strengthen interconnections between leading European infrastructures: (DARIAH, ARIADNE, CLARIN, OPERAS) to improve access to a portfolio of state-of-the-art services available to researchers across countries, languages, domains and media. This project will build on a shared understanding and interoperability principles established in the SSHOC (Social Sciences & Humanities Open Cloud) cluster project and other previous collaborations.
For more information about ATRIUM please visit the project website.

title: Applications
text: The ADS Winter School is part of the ATRIUM Transnational Access (TNA) Scheme. More information about the scheme can be found on the ATRIUM website on the TNA pages.

title: Applications
text:
‚úçÔ∏è Apply here
ATRIUM‚Äôs Transnational Access (TNA) scheme offers researchers the possibility to apply for a fully funded placement at a number of different partner organisations to access expert knowledge and advice from leading Data Management organisations across Europe. The ADS Winter School is one of a number available via the TNA scheme. For a full list please see the list of Host Organisations at the bottom of the TNA webpages.






Tip



Applications to the ADS Training School should be made through this online form

title: Applications
text:
Application Process
For more information about eligibility requirements, the information required and Frequently Asked Questions can be found on the Application pages.






Important



Only applicants with organisational affiliations outside of the UK are eligible to receive funding.


If you are successful in your application you are required to: - Provide feedback to the ADS on training school after your visit. - Provide ATRIUM with the details of any outputs resulting from the TNA scheme.

title: Information
text: The training school will take place from Monday 11th November to Friday 15th November 2024.

title: Information
text: The training school will take place from Monday 11th November to Friday 15th November 2024.

title: Information
text:
üåç Location
The session will be held in person at the main offices of the Archaeology Data Service. Please see the map below for the exact location.
The address of the ADS offices are:

King‚Äôs Manor Exhibition Square, York, YO1 7EP United Kingdom

title: Information
text:
üìñ Expenses
The ADS Training School is facilitated through the ATRIUM project Transnational Access Scheme. By applying to this scheme expenses incurred through attending the training school will be reimbursed to successful applicants.
This scheme covers the following expenses:

International travel (including all travel costs within the UK)
Accommodation for the duration of the training school
Subsistence expenses (up to the value of 280 Euros for the week)

title: Information
text:
‚úàÔ∏è Travelling to York
The nearest airport to the University is Manchester Airport and there is a direct train from London from Kings Cross Station. Kings Cross is a short walk from St Pancras International Station, which is served by the Eurostar. For more information about travelling to York international please visit the ‚ÄòArriving from Overseas‚Äô webpage on the University of York website.
More information is accessible via the Univeristy of York‚Äôs travel webpages.

title: Information
text:
üè® Accomadation
York has a number of choices for accommodation in and around the city. Please look at the Visit York website for more information. If you are accepted to the Winter School, we would be happy to provide you with some suggestions about where to stay in York.

title: Schedule
text:
Assignments
Below are assignment due dates for the semester. You can find details and assignment instructions in the relevant week on the schedule.

Homework
Homework will be due on Wednesdays at 11:59pm. You will have one week to complete each homework assignment.


Labs
Labs will be due on Fridays at 11:59pm. You will start the lab during your scheduled lab section.


Exams
There will be two exams on the dates:

October 12, 9am - October 14, 11:59pm
November 16, 9am - November 16: 11:59pm
